so this is what um Android automotive looks like so starting at the bottom down here
we have the vehicle ecus uh electronic control units so
these are the things which are controlling all the bits and pieces in your car so they're doing some trivial
things like turning lights on and off the headlights and such like and they're doing some major things like control in
the engine the engine management unit is one of these these are all connected together
via some kind of vehicle bus most cases this is going to be
canvas and then the interface between the ecus and Android is a how how is the
hardware abstraction layer and the particular how we're talking about here is the vehicle how so the vehicle how
is uh interfacing between the vehicle bus and the rest of
Android the how then is talking up to the next level up which over here forg get my like to work um so the next level
up is the car service so this is a system service part of the Android

and and presenting apis uh to Applications based on information from

this is android. car. jar so this is the the library that applications will link

Android uh implementations so I'm going to go

vhal so the vhal then is collecting signals from the from the vehicle bus
from the can bus and storing them in vehicle

be the speed of the vehicle so that is relayed from wherever which whichever

properties and feed them all the way from the ECU up to the
application um Android automotive OS defines um
three different uh modes of change so properties are either static never
change unchange so that means that they change
intermittently and we want to know as soon as the change happens so for example the gear
selector um forward reverse Park Drive whatever we want to know as soon as that
gear selector is changed because that's going to you know that's something we're interested in or the door unlock we want
to know immediately that the doors are unlocked whatever so on change we want
to know immediately the value changes and then continuous this is for
things which are always changing so the speed the temperature that kind of stuff
um so a non-change notification wouldn't work there so in this case we label it
being continuous and then we set a sampling rate in hertz as to how often
we want to be notified of that change so if it's the temperature you probably want to be notified maybe once every 10
seconds or something if you're monitoring the speed you probably want to be notified maybe 10 times a second
or something

audio is uh a tricky thing in a vehicle so whereas with a smartphone audio is

that you can plug in headphones in a vehicle it's very much more
complicated uh you've got multiple output channels you got speakers all over the place um you know smart um

so there are some changes to Android automotive uh to handle this
[Music] um the main thing is so here's here's a diagram from
uh developer sorry source. android.com so up here at the top we
have a number of applications each producing uh audio streams so there's the navigation app
there's the uh radio app there's the streaming media app and so on
so they are feeding those streams to a thing called surface to audio flinger so
audio flinger is essentially the audio mixer in Android so that's taking all these
channels together and then it does a submix mixes down into a smaller number of
channels and this is the this is the main thing that's different between Android automotive and regular Android
so with regular Android you have basically just one output from audio flinger with Android automotive you have
as many as you want so these are called buses and each bus is an output from
audio flinger that's then fed into the audio amplifier and that's then fed to
an appropriate set of speakers so we can feed these we can
essentially we can root the audio to different sets of speakers uh and we do that based on the
content of the audio so a good example would be the navigation app uh its audio
stream will be tagged as being uh typed navigation that will be detected in
audio flinger and then audio flinger will then root that typically to the driver side of the vehicle because the
driver is probably more interested in the navigation than anyone
else so these are the audio context So within Android you can label an audio
stream with a context uh here's an example or some
examples and then um those contexts are

buses and yeah here's my example about the navigation context typically being being used to select routing towards the

something so these are called Chimes and warnings uh many of them are mandated by
by regulations so you have to do this and it's an error if they don't uh play
correctly so once again because Android is not a safe critical operating system
